definition: to guard/to defend/to keep watch/to abide by the law/to observe (rules or ritual)/nearby/adjoining

sentences.english: Maybe she dresses well, is efficient or extremely punctual.
sentences.chinese: 比如，誇女孩衣着得體，辦事有效率或者是極其守時。

sentences.english: A: First they’d say I am very punctual.
sentences.chinese: 首先他們會說我是一個非常守時的人。

sentences.english: He is punctual. He never breaks his words.
We should try to be punctual forever.
sentences.chinese: 我們應該儘量做到永遠守時。

sentences.english: Another example. You have a feeling that even though you're usually on time,
sentences.chinese: 再說一個例子。儘管你一直是個守時的人，

sentences.english: If you want to become more punctual, clarify the concept behind the definition of what you are.
sentences.chinese: 如果你想變得更加守時，弄清楚這對你的意義。

sentences.english: Never mind on defend-stick or shooting-block some issue therefor.
sentences.chinese: 對於防守時的卡位或是射擊時的擋住隊友都無須掛心。

sentences.english: The principle, design and manufacture of this type of Hydrogen maser are described in this…
sentences.chinese: 本文將描述這種守時型氫脈澤標準的設計與研製情況。

sentences.english: His habit of punctuality has not changed since he was eight years old.
sentences.chinese: 他守時的習慣自八歲以來一直沒改。

sentences.english: The unpunctual man , on the other hand, never does what he has to do at the proper time .
sentences.chinese: 反之，不守時的人從不按時完成他應該做的事。

sentences.english: His unpunctuality served as an excuse to get rid of him.
sentences.chinese: 他的不守時成爲開除他的藉口。

sentences.english: As exactness is kindness, he was exact.
sentences.chinese: 因爲守時是一種仁愛，他總是守時的。

sentences.english: As exactness is kindness, he was exact.
sentences.chinese: 因爲守時是一種仁愛，他總是守時的。

sentences.english: No punctuality is a bad habit. We should get rid of it.
sentences.chinese: 不守時是壞習慣，我們應改掉它。

sentences.english: She said bitterly to me that this was as bad as being praised for punctuality.
sentences.chinese: 她忿忿地對我說，這就跟被稱讚守時一樣糟糕。

sentences.english: When we defend, everyone take responsibility.
sentences.chinese: 防守時，每個人各盡其責。

definition: see 念念不忘[nian4 nian4 bu4 wang4]
to show every possible consideration (idiom); meticulous care
benevolent heart and skillful execution (idiom, from Mencius); charitable in thought and deed
to bury oneself in work (idiom); to be engrossed in work/to make an all-out effort/up to the neck in work
lit. to point at the mulberry tree and curse the locust tree/fig. to scold sb indirectly/to make oblique accusations (idiom)
competitive/ambitious and aggressive/to desire to beat others
to choose what is good and hold fast to it (idiom)
to praise the virtue of sb or sth while concealing their faults
